conclusion: Consider power, collision, and deflection effects to determine which blocks A will collide with and where it will stop.
A is moving from the right side of the image towards the left, heading towards a group of blocks.
A will likely collide with the first block it encounters, hitting the red block closest to its path.
A has enough power to move through the blocks, but the exact force will determine how many blocks it can move before stopping.
Upon collision, A may be deflected slightly depending on the angle and the rigidity of the blocks.
After the first collision, A will continue moving and may collide with additional blocks, with the path depending on deflection from each collision.
A will eventually stop when it either runs out of power or is blocked by a configuration of blocks it cannot move through.
A will collide with multiple blocks, starting with the red block closest to its path, and will eventually stop after moving through several blocks, depending on its power and deflection effects.
